Web Design Projects

by Alex Kozlov

About

This webpage contains the projects I've completed as part of the various freeCodeCamp web development certifications. The first section "HTML / CSS Projects" contains webpage projects implemented in HTML / CSS only. The second section "JavaScript Projects" contains algorithm projects implemented purely in JavaScript. The third section "React Projects" contains web app projects I implemented using the React front-end framework. The fourth section "D3 Projects" presents data visualisation projects I completed using the D3.js data visualisation library. Please see each individual section for further details.

HTML / CSS Projects

I've designed and implemented five web page projects as part of the freeCodeCamp "Responsive Web Design" certification. This includes the page you are currently viewing, and the four pages linked below.

Each project had a high-level requirement (e.g. build a "tribute webpage") and a suite of tests it had to satisfy. The tests checked for the presence of certain HTML elements and attributes, and CSS stylings. Beyond that, the design and content of each web page was left up to the developer. Each web page was implemented using HTML and CSS only.

Below you can find information about each web page, and a link to view it. When you open the link by default you will be taken to "Full Page View", which just shows the webpage. You can view the full HTML and CSS source by clicking on the "Change View" button at the top-right of the screen, and selecting "Editor View".

Project 1: Tribute Page

The high level requirement for this project was to build a Tribute Page, on any subject. The test suite checked for the presence of a basic HTML structure and certain elements such as a captioned image, a main content element and an external link. The design and content of my page are original, with the exception of the externally linked image. Click on the image to the right to view it.

Click here for Tribute Page

Project 2: Survey Form

The second project was to build a Survey Web Form, again on any subject. The test suite here checked for various web form input elements such as a dropdown list, radio buttons and checkboxes. The design and content of my page are original. Please note that you can't actually submit the form, as there is no backend.

Click here for Survey Form

Project 3: Product Page

The third project was to build a Product Page for a fictional shop or service provider. The test suite for this page checked for particular elements such as a navigation bar, an embedded video and an email web form. The design and content are original except for the logo image and the embedded video. Again please note that you can't actually sign up with an email address.

Click here for Product Page

Project 4: Documentation Page

The requirement for this project was to build a Technical Documentation Page. The test suite here checked for fairly strict adherence to a documentation-style structure, and for related elements such as code snippets. The styling of the page is original but I took the content from the freeCodeCamp example solution, which was a JavaScript tutorial. I felt it was beneficial to study it as I was unfamiliar with JavaScript at the time.

Click here for Doc. Page

JavaScript Projects

This section contains algorithm projects I've implemented purely in JavaScript, as part of the freeCodeCamp "JavaScript Algorithms and Data Structures" certification. Each project consists of a single JavaScript source file which contains documentation on the requirements, the implementation and usage examples.

Clicking on a link below will take you to the "Editor View" showing you the source file, and a JavaScript console where you can run the examples. If the console is not open, click on the "Console" button at the bottom left of the screen. You can then copy the examples from the source file into the console, in order to execute them. Please see each individual source file for further details.

Project 1: Palindrome Checker

A palindrome is a word or sentence that is spelled the same way both forward and backward, ignoring punctuation, case and spacing. This program filters the input string to remove all non-alphanumeric characters and then checks whether the string is a palindrome.

Click here for Palindrome Checker

Project 2: Roman Numeral Converter

This program converts a given decimal number into a Roman Numeral. Due to the limitation of characters that I can print on the console, the maximum convertable number is 3999 which is "MMMCMXCIX".

Click here for Roman Numeral Converter

Project 3: Caesars Cipher

In Caesars Cipher, also known as Shift Cipher, the meanings of the letters are shifted by a set amount. This program implements the ROT13 cipher where the letters are shifted by 13 places. E.g. 'A' becomes 'N', 'B' becomes 'O', etc. It takes a ROT13 encoded string and returns a decoded string.

Click here for Caesars Cipher

Project 4: Phone Number Validator

Checks whether the given string has the format of a valid US phone number. This is mainly a regex filtering excercise in removing invalid characters, accounting for separators, and checking for valid formats.

Click here for Phone Number Validator

Project 5: Cash Register

Implements a cash register drawer function that accepts a purchase price, cash payment amount, and a "cash-in-drawer" array of available currencies. Calculates the required change for the purchase, in the currencies available in the "cash-in-drawer" array.

Click here for Cash Register

Project 6: Orbital Period

The orbital period is the time a given astronomical object takes to complete one orbit around another object. This project computes the orbital period of objects around the Earth, given their average altitude. It's nothing too complicated, but I thought it was quite interesting.

Click here for Orbital Period

React Projects

This section contains web app projects I've developed using the React front-end framework, as part of the freeCodeCamp "Front End Libraries" certification. Similarly to the "HTML" projects above, each project had a high level requirement and a set of tests it had to pass. Beyond the high level requirement, the styling and content of each app was up to the developer. The tests generally checked for the presence of certain DOM elements, and for the required interactivity existing in these elements when a user interacts with them.

When opening a project link below, by default you will be taken to "Full Page View". You can view the full React/JavaScript source by changing to "Editor View" and examining the "JS" Editor. To maximise the JS editor click on the arrow button at the top-right in the editor, and select "Maximise JS Editor".

In addition you can use the React Developer Tools browser extension to view the runtime component hierarchy and state. After installing the extension, from the "Change View" menu select "Debug mode". Note that it may be necessary to "Fork" the CodePen project first, in order for "Debug mode" to become available. Once on the "Debug mode" page, open the browser developer tools ("Ctrl + Shift + K" in Firefox or "Ctrl + Shift + J" in Chrome) and select the "Components" tab. You can then click on a component to view its state and props.

In some of these projects I've also used the Redux state management framework in combination with React, using the React-Redux bindings. Although using Redux isn't really necessary for small projects such as these, I primarily wanted to do it as an exercise to get a better understanding of Redux and its applicability.

Project 1: Quote Generator

A simple web app that displays a random quote from the provided array of quotes. Implemented purely in React as a single stateful component. The array of available quotes to choose from is passed in as a property.

Click here for Quote Generator

Project 2: Markdown Previewer

A simple app consisting of an editor and a preview panel. The app previews markdown text as it is typed into the editor. The editor and the preview panel can be individually maximised. Implemented purely in React as a single stateful component and a couple of stateless functional child components.

Click here for Markdown Previewer

Project 3: Drum Machine

An app that plays audio drum samples when keys are pressed or the buttons are clicked. Implemented in React in combination with Redux for state management. I primarily wanted to use Redux as an exercise to get a better understanding of it and its applicability. This is probably the most "fun" project in my opinion. Try listening to a slow to mid tempo heavy metal or hard rock track, and keeping the beat!

Click here for Drum Machine

Project 4: JavaScript Calculator

A calculator app which performs basic integer and floating point arithmetic. Implemented in React in combination with Redux for state management. Again I used Redux here mainly as an exercise.

Click here for Calculator

Project 5: Pomodoro Clock

A countdown timer that alternates between session and break periods. Rings a chime when each period completes. Can be paused and resumed, and the session and break durations can be changed. Implemented in React in combination with Redux for state management.

Click here for Clock

D3 Projects

This section presents the projects I completed using the D3.js data visualisation library, as part of the freeCodeCamp "Data Visualization" certification. These projects involved fetching data and creating different types of data plots. The automated tests for each project checked for correct plotting of the required data, and additional elements like axes, tick labels and tooltips. For each project the data for plotting was fetched in JSON format using AJAX. You can view the full D3/JavaScript source by changing to "Editor View" and examining the "JS" Editor.

Project 1: Bar Chart

Uses the D3.js library to plot a bar chart of US GDP data over time. On mouse-over the given bar is highlighted and a tooltip is displayed. The chart resizes responsively. The data for plotting is fetched in JSON format via AJAX.

Click here for Bar Chart

Project 2: Scatterplot

Plots a scatterplot with D3.js which presents doping allegations data in professional cycling. The data points are color-coded to differentiate between cyclists with and without doping allegations. A tooltip presents additional information about each data point. The data is fetched with AJAX.

Click here for Scatterplot

Project 3: Heat Map

Plots a heat map visualising global land surface temperature over months and years. Each cell shows the temperature for a given month of a given year. The temperature value is color coded using the color scale shown in the legend. Each cell also displays a tooltip showing the exact temperature value.

Click here for Heat Map

Project 4: Choropleth Map

A choropleth is a geographic map which uses color to encode additional information. This choropleth plots a map of the U.S. by state and county. Each county is color coded to show the education level of its residents. On hover a tooltip shows the county name and the exact percentage education level.

Click here for Choropleth

Project 5: Treemap

A treemap chart subdivides the plot area into rectangular cells, where the size of each cell is proportional to an associated value. This treemap plots the top most sold video game titles by platform. The area of each cell (the "value") indicates the relative volume of sales of the video game title. The color of each cell indicates the gaming platform.

Click here for Treemap
